<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 279, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 186, 907, 202]]<|/det|>
0625/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 208, 907, 223]]<|/det|>
May/June 2012  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 229, 907, 244]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 589, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 330]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 343, 235, 358]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 358, 601, 374]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 373, 892, 404]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 415, 892, 446]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 445, 890, 462]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 473, 556, 491]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 503, 764, 535]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 271, 712, 288]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 299, 133, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 299, 460, 317]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 421, 106, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 420, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
An engineer wants to fix a steel washer on to a steel rod. The rod is just too big to fit into the hole of the washer.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 464, 774, 549]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 559, 534, 577]]<|/det|>
How can the engineer fit the washer on to the rod?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 587, 133, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 587, 480, 605]]<|/det|>
Cool the washer and put it over the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 615, 133, 632]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 615, 771, 632]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 791, 91]]<|/det|> A circuit-breaker is designed to protect a circuit which usually carries a current of 2 A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 792, 121]]<|/det|> The time taken to break the circuit depends on the current, as shown in the graph. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 128, 796, 365]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 394, 887, 413]]<|/det|> What happens when the current in the circuit is 2A and what happens when the current 18A? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 422, 881, 553]]<|/det|>
when the current is 2Awhen the current is 18A
Athe circuit breaks in less than 5 secondsthe circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds
Bthe circuit breaks in less than 5 secondsthe circuit does not break
Cthe circuit does not breakthe circuit breaks in less than 5 seconds
Dthe circuit does not breakthe circuit does not break
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 580, 107, 599]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 580, 920, 615]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a coil connected to a battery and a switch. Two unmagnetised iron bars hang freely near opposite ends of the coil. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 617, 811, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 797, 593, 816]]<|/det|> What happens to the iron bars when the switch is closed? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 826, 134, 845]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 826, 475, 845]]<|/det|> Both X and Y move away from the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 853, 134, 871]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 853, 455, 871]]<|/det|> Both X and Y move towards the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 880, 131, 898]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 880, 603, 898]]<|/det|> X moves towards the coil, Y moves away from the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 906, 133, 924]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 906, 603, 924]]<|/det|> Y moves towards the coil, X moves away from the coil.

There is a current in the direction shown, and this causes a force to act on the wire. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 112, 638, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 813, 291]]<|/det|> Three other arrangements, P, Q and R, of the wire and magnet are set up as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 295, 843, 457]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 920, 508]]<|/det|> Which arrangement or arrangements will cause a force in the same direction as the original arrangement? part heatedreason

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 447, 92]]<|/det|> A radioactive nucleus emits a \(\beta\) -particle. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 97, 640, 210]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 688, 242]]<|/det|> What happens to the proton number (atomic number) of the nucleus? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 250, 134, 268]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 250, 299, 268]]<|/det|> It stays the same. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 277, 133, 295]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 277, 295, 295]]<|/det|> It increases by 1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 303, 133, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 303, 299, 322]]<|/det|> It decreases by 2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 133, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 330, 299, 348]]<|/det|> It decreases by 4. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 373, 106, 392]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 373, 752, 392]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the paths of three different types of radiation, X, Y and Z. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 400, 715, 549]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 558, 559, 577]]<|/det|> Which row in the table correctly identifies X, Y and Z? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 588, 576, 718]]<|/det|>
